review.title: Comparison of algorithms that detect drug side effects using electronic healthcare databases
review.abstract: The electronic healthcare databases are starting to become more readily available and are thought to have excellent potential for generating adverse drug reaction signals. The Health Improvement Network (THIN) database is an electronic healthcare database containing medical information on over 11 million patients that has excellent potential for detecting ADRs. In this paper we apply four existing electronic healthcare database signal detecting algorithms (MUTARA, HUNT, Temporal Pattern Discovery and modified ROR) on the THIN database for a selection of drugs from six chosen drug families. This is the first comparison of ADR signalling algorithms that includes MUTARA and HUNT and enabled us to set a benchmark for the adverse drug reaction signalling ability of the THIN database. The drugs were selectively chosen to enable a comparison with previous work and for variety. It was found that no algorithm was generally superior and the algorithms' natural thresholds act at variable stringencies. Furthermore, none of the algorithms perform well at detecting rare ADRs.

metadata.title: Comparison of Algorithms that Detect Drug Side Effects using Electronic Healthcare Databases

sections.text: Health Improvement Network (THIN) Database is an electronic health database with medical information about more than 11 million patients, which has excellent potential for recognizing ADRs. In this work, we apply four existing electronic signal recognition algorithms from the health database (MUTARA, HUNT, Temporal Pattern Discovery and modified ROR) to the THIN database for the selection of medicines from six selected drug families. It was found that no algorithm was generally superior and the natural thresholds of algorithms are effective in variable severity. Furthermore, none of the algorithms is good at detecting rare ADRs.Keywords Adverse drug event · BB LonukMouloulic Modected · Health Improvement Network (THIN) No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 2 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 2 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 2 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 2 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 2 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 2 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 2 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 2 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No. 1 No

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: This year, it has reached the stage where it will be able to take the lead.

sections.heading: 2 Algorithms
sections.text: The EHDs do not contain any direct linkages between medications and medical events that represent potential ADRs, but these linkages can be closed based on the time information in the database and find any medical events that occur within a specified period of time after the medication is prescribed. In this post, we examine the ability to detect imminent ADRs, so that we consider all medical events that occur within 30 days of the medication being prescribed as possible drug and ADR pairs. The justification for investigating the 30-day period after a drug is that this is a compromise between a sufficiently long period of time during which underreporting is minimized (as patients have time to report side effects), while reducing the amount of noise by a long period of time. After all medical events that occur within 30 days of the medication being prescribed are found, the pharmacovigilance algorithms developed for EHDs then calculate a dependence between the list of any medical event and any medical event that occur within 30 days of each medical event.

sections.heading: 2.1.1 SRS Algorithms & Background
sections.text: The SRS algorithms were originally developed for general SRS databases, where the actual rate at which a drug is prescribed and the rate at which a medical event occurs is unknown, since the SRS databases contain only data on the medicines prescriptions that may have led to an ADR. Consequently, the SRS algorithms estimate the background rate at which a medical event occurs by figuring out how often the medical event is reported with each drug in the database. Medical events that are reported disproportionately more frequently with the drug of interest compared to all the other medications in the database are then classified as highly suspicious ADRs. These algorithms use an emergency table, see Table 1, summarizing the number of reports that contain (or do not include) the drug and the event of interest. An example of an SRS algorithm is the probability of a medical event occurring (ROR), w00 = 1 w1 (11 / 1) after a drug occurs relatively frequent (11 / 1).

sections.heading: 2.1.2 SRS algorithms Previous Results
sections.text: Existing work by Zorych et al. converted the "modified SRS algorithms" to a simulated EHD database and a real EHD database [28]. First, they converted the EHD databases into an SRS database containing reports on potential drug and ADR pairs by applying temporal relationships similar to those described at the beginning of this section, see Figure 1. After transforming the EHD data into SRS data, they converted the existing SRS disproportionality algorithms.

sections.heading: 2.1.3 Implementation of the modified SRS algorithms in this study
sections.text: In this paper, we use the transformation of the "spontaneous notification system" [28], where SRS-style reports consisting of a patient, a drug prescription and possible adverse events are derived from the EHD by detecting all medical events occurring within 30 days of a drug prescription. Figure 1 illustrates an example of the transformation. After the THIN database has been transformed, as described in Figure 1, ROR is applied. The left limit of the 90% confidence interval of ROR (ROR05) is calculated for each event occurring in at least three reports of interest to the drug (w00 ≥ 3) and the medical events are evaluated based on ROR05, see Equation 2 [17] [28]. We opted for the left limit of the 90% confidence interval of ROR, as previous work has shown that the ROR05 was better in terms of probability of medical events being RADR28 than the ROR [28].

sections.heading: 2.2 MUTARA/HUNT
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 2.2.1 MUTARA/HUNT Background
sections.text: The algorithms Mining Unexpected Temporary Association Rules given the Antecedent (MUTARA) [11] and Highlighting UTARs, Negating TARs (HUNT) [12] were designed to be implemented on the QueenslandLinked Data Set (QLDS), which consists of the Commonwealth Medicare Benefits Scheme (MBS), Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) and Queensland Hospital Morbidity Data. QLDS included hospital data from 1 July 1995 to 30 June 1999 and MBS / PBS data from 1 January 1995 to 31 December 1999. Medical events from hospital data were recorded by the International Statistical Classification of Diseases and Related Health Problems (ICD) 9 System, and there were a total of 758 different diagnoses in 2020. Drug prescriptions were encoded with the World Health Organisation (WHO) Anatomical Therapeutic Chemical (ATC) and the database contained a total of 758 different drug codes.

sections.heading: 2.2.3 MUTARA/HUNT Previous Results
sections.text: MUTARA was applied to QLDS in older women with alendronate, and among the first ten events returned by the algorithm was reflux esophagitis, a known side effect. The two most important events returned by MUTARA were associated with osteoporosis, the cause of taking the drug, and the other events were not listed and were considered likely to be adverse drug events, suggesting that the accuracy of the first ten events (P (10) 0.1 for the alendronate applied to the QLDS with a specific strategy. HUNT was applied to the QLDS for the drug alendronate and the stratum consisting of older women. Results show that HUNT yielded three known ADRs within the ten returned events, corresponding to a P (10) = 0.3. When alendronate was investigated in older men, an ADR was returned (10 = 0.1).

sections.heading: 2.2.4 Implementation of MUTARA/HUNT in this study
sections.text: The reason for the selection of 30 days is consistency with the other algorithms in this study, which allows a fairer comparison. We did not implement stratification and the chosen study period included all records from the years 1900-2010. The algorithms MUTARA60 and HUNT60 referred to in the continuation of this work were MUTARA and HUNT implemented with Tc = Te = 30, Tr = Tb = 60, and the algorithms MUTARA180 and HUNT180 referred to in the continuation of this work were MUTARA and HUNT implemented with Tc = Te = 30, Tr = Tb = 180.

sections.heading: 2.3.1 TPD Ratio Background
sections.text: Noren et al. developed the Temporal Pattern Discovery (TPD) algorithm on the basis of a measure of disproportionality [15], which is very similar to the disproportionality methods used on SRS databases. Similar to the THIN database, the UK IMS Disease Analyzer extracts data directly from the computers of resident physicians, with over two million comparisons of drug adverse reaction algorithms containing 7 patients and 120 million prescriptions. Similar to the THIN database, the UK IMS Disease Analyzer extracts data directly from the computers of resident physicians, and the OE ratio was implemented into patient records by December 31, 2005. The database contained 3445 medicines and 5753 medical events encoded by ICD-10 [26].

sections.heading: 2.3.2 TPD algorithms
sections.text: The TPD algorithm compares the number of patients who have prescribed the first drug in thirteen months q = q followed by event y within a given time t relative to the expected number of patients if drug x and event y were independent. The expected number of patients who have used drug x and then event x is then an event y within a period. sections.text: The algorithm was applied to the UK IMS Disease Analyzer database for the drug nifedipine and found seven known ADRs among the ten returned non-administrative events. This corresponds to a P (10) = 0.7.

sections.heading: 4.3 AP
sections.text: In fact, most of them are able to play by the rules they have established in the past, and they are able to play by the rules they have established in the past.

sections.heading: 5.3 AP
sections.text: Overall, no algorithm consistently performed better than the other across all the drugs studied in this study, but either TPD 1 or HUNT had the highest AP in most of the drugs studied. ROR05 generally performed worse, but still had a higher AP than the other algorithms for the drug phenoxymethylpenicillin. Since we know how often each drug was prescribed, the average age of the patients who prescribed each drug, and the male percentage of patients who prescribed the drug, we discuss how these factors affected the various algorithms below.

sections.heading: 5.3.1 Age
sections.text: The drugs prescribed to the youngest patients were penicillins. TPD 1 delivered the highest AP for flucloxacillin, amoxicillin and phenoxymethylpenicillin, and HUNT60 delivered the highest AP for benzyl penicillin sodium and ampicillin. This is consistent with overall results, as TPD 1 and HUNT60 generally had the highest AP value of any medication, which is regrettable as stratification of all algorithms in the study is likely to lead to an increase in the time it takes to identify an ADR, as the population of patients on average being prescribed a drug may require the algorithms to apply stratification methods instead of applying the algorithms to all age groups.

sections.heading: 5.3.2 Gender Bias
sections.text: The drugs with the greatest gender bias towards women (which are more commonly prescribed to women) were norfloxacin, lofepramine, nortriptyline and doxepine, with male ratios of 0.26,0,28, 0.29 and 0.32, respectively. Aside from lofepramine, MUTARA and HUNT performed much better on medications prescribed to more women than men. This may underscore the need for MUTARA and HUNT to be prescribed more frequently to a subgroup of patients, such as elderly women or young men, as was originally the case for MUTATA and HUNT.The medications gliclazides, glibenclamide, glipizides and glimepirides are more commonly prescribed to men than to women with a male ratio of 0.55, 0.54, 0.53 and 0.53, respectively. These medications had the lowest AP levels compared to all the other medicines studied and may suggest that the algorithms have difficulty detecting ADHD more frequently in malaria, which are more commonly prescribed to malaria.

sections.heading: 5.3.3 Low Prescription Rates
sections.text: This year it is so far that it will only take one year to move on to the next round.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions
sections.text: In this paper, we compared four existing ADR detection algorithms by applying them to the THIN database for a number of medications, and measured how well they rated the known ADRs or known ADRs at their natural thresholds. We found that the benchmark AP score for ADRs of signal algorithms applied to the THIN database is 0.2, the benchmark AUC [0.0.1] is 0.011 (3dp) and AUC [0.0.3] is 0.076 (3dp). Future algorithms should aim for higher values. Results show that no algorithm was superior for all medications considered, although the results suggest that HUNT may be the optimal algorithm to apply when the number of patients being prescribed the drug is low or TPD may be optimal when patients are old, but further research is needed to confirm these hypotheses.

metadata.abstractText: The electronic healthcare databases are starting to become more readily available and are thought to have excellent potential for generating adverse drug reaction signals. The Health Improvement Network (THIN) database is an electronic healthcare database containing medical information on over 11 million patients that has excellent potential for detecting ADRs. In this paper we apply four existing electronic healthcare database signal detecting algorithms (MUTARA, HUNT, Temporal Pattern Discovery and modified ROR) on the THIN database for a selection of drugs from six chosen drug families. This is the first comparison of ADR signalling algorithms that includes MUTARA and HUNT and enabled us to set a benchmark for the adverse drug reaction signalling ability of the THIN database. The drugs were selectively chosen to enable a comparison with previous work and for variety. It was found that no algorithm was generally superior and the algorithms’ natural thresholds act at variable stringencies. Furthermore, none of the algorithms perform well at detecting rare ADRs.
